true: Earth is the fifth largest planet in the solar system.
Earth is 93 million miles away from the Sun.
Earth’s atmosphere is composed of 78% nitrogen and 21% oxygen.
Earth has a magnetic field that protects it from solar radiation.
The Earth orbits the Sun once every 365.25 days.
Earth's axis is tilted at 23.4 degrees, which causes the seasons.
Earth is the only planet known to support life.
70% of Earth's surface is covered by water.
The Earth's Moon is about 1,080 miles in radius.
The Earth's magnetic poles reverse approximately every 400,000 years.
fake: Earth has two moons, the second being a small asteroid named 'Luna II'.
The Earth completes one full rotation every 40 hours.
Earth's core is made entirely of liquid water, which supports aquatic life inside the planet.
The Earth’s atmosphere extends to the Moon, which is why we see blue skies on the Moon.
Earth’s gravitational force changes based on the phase of the Moon.
The tallest mountain on Earth, Mauna Kea, reaches into outer space.
Earth was formed 10 billion years ago, making it the oldest planet in the solar system.
Earth’s oceans contain 50% of the solar system's total water.
Earth has a permanent dust storm circulating over the Sahara Desert.
Earth’s core is the primary source of the planet’s magnetic field.

true: The Moon is the fifth-largest natural satellite in the solar system.
The Moon is about 238,855 miles (384,400 kilometers) away from Earth.
The Moon has no atmosphere, which means there's no weather or wind on its surface.
The Moon’s gravity is about 1/6th of Earth’s gravity.
The Moon was formed about 4.5 billion years ago, likely from debris after a massive collision with Earth.
The Moon completes one full orbit around Earth in about 27.3 days.
The Moon's surface is covered with craters, formed by impacts from meteoroids.
A full 'supermoon' appears up to 14% larger and 30% brighter than when the Moon is farthest from Earth.
The Moon's gravitational pull is responsible for creating tides on Earth.
The Moon's crust is about 43 miles (70 kilometers) thick on its near side.
fake: The Moon has its own magnetic field that is five times stronger than Earth's.
The Moon has underground lakes of liquid water that sustain small life forms.
The Moon rotates so fast that a full day on the Moon lasts only 3 hours.
The Moon is slowly moving closer to Earth by 4 inches (10 centimeters) every year.
The Moon is primarily composed of liquid mercury, which is why it reflects sunlight so well.
The Moon’s surface temperature can reach up to 1000 degrees Fahrenheit during the day.
The Moon was once a part of Venus and was ejected into space due to volcanic activity.
The Moon has active volcanoes that erupt every 50 years.
The Moon's gravity causes Earth to spin faster over time.
During lunar eclipses, the Moon turns blue because of its unique mineral composition.

true: Mars is about half the size of Earth, with a radius of 2,106 miles (3,390 kilometers).
Mars has two small moons, Phobos and Deimos.
A day on Mars, called a sol, is slightly longer than a day on Earth, lasting about 24.6 hours.
Mars is known as the Red Planet due to iron minerals in the Martian soil oxidizing and turning red.
Olympus Mons on Mars is the tallest volcano in the solar system, three times taller than Mount Everest.
Mars has a thin atmosphere made mostly of carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and argon gases.
The surface temperature on Mars can vary from 70°F (20°C) to -225°F (-153°C).
Mars has seasons, like Earth, due to its axial tilt of 25 degrees.
Valles Marineris on Mars is one of the largest canyon systems in the solar system, stretching over 3,000 miles (4,800 kilometers).
Mars has evidence of ancient water in the form of river valleys, deltas, and lakebeds.
fake: Mars has a ring system similar to Saturn, but it’s made of magnetic dust particles.
Mars rotates twice as fast as Earth, completing a full rotation every 12 hours.
The atmosphere on Mars is primarily composed of helium, which gives the sky a yellow tint.
Mars’ surface is covered by large oceans of liquid methane.
Mars has giant trees that grow in its canyons, capable of surviving in extreme temperatures.
The gravity on Mars is twice as strong as Earth's, making it difficult for rovers to move.
Mars has an active core that causes frequent volcanic eruptions every 100 years.
The planet's red color is due to bacteria in the soil that survived from ancient times.
Phobos and Deimos, Mars’ moons, were artificially created by ancient civilizations.
Mars has permanent glowing clouds that illuminate the night side of the planet.

true: Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system, with a radius of 43,440.7 miles (69,911 kilometers).
Jupiter is 5.2 astronomical units away from the Sun, which is about 484 million miles (778 million kilometers).
Jupiter has the shortest day of all the planets, taking only about 10 hours to complete a full rotation.
The Great Red Spot on Jupiter is a massive storm that has raged for more than 300 years.
Jupiter has 95 moons, with the four largest being Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.
Europa, one of Jupiter’s moons, is believed to have a vast ocean beneath its icy crust, potentially supporting life.
Jupiter’s atmosphere is composed mainly of hydrogen and helium, similar to the Sun.
Jupiter’s fast rotation generates strong jet streams that separate the planet’s clouds into belts and zones.
The magnetic field of Jupiter is 16 to 54 times stronger than Earth’s magnetic field.
Jupiter's rings were discovered in 1979 by NASA's Voyager 1 spacecraft and are composed of small, dark particles.
fake: Jupiter's Great Red Spot is shrinking and will disappear completely within the next 50 years.
The atmosphere of Jupiter contains a significant amount of oxygen, which makes the skies blue like on Earth.
Jupiter’s largest moon, Ganymede, has active volcanoes that erupt every 10 years.
Jupiter rotates so fast that objects on its surface experience zero gravity for half of the day.
Jupiter’s core is made of pure diamond, which formed under the intense pressure of the planet’s gravity.
Jupiter's rings are composed of frozen methane and glow bright green when exposed to sunlight.
Jupiter’s magnetic field causes it to generate artificial sunlight, making it shine as a second sun in the solar system.
The planet's fast winds produce sounds that can be detected from Earth with the naked ear during solar eclipses.
Jupiter's poles experience daily snowstorms made of frozen hydrogen that accumulate in thick layers.
The surface of Jupiter has large continents made of solid ammonia ice that shift due to tidal forces.

true: Saturn is the second-largest planet in the solar system, with a diameter of about 74,897 miles (120,500 kilometers).
Saturn's iconic rings are made up of billions of pieces of ice and rock, some as small as dust and others as large as houses.
Saturn has at least 146 confirmed moons, with Titan being the largest.
Saturn’s day lasts only about 10.7 hours due to its fast rotation.
Saturn's rings are about 175,000 miles (282,000 kilometers) wide but only about 30 feet (10 meters) thick.
Titan, Saturn’s largest moon, has lakes of liquid methane and ethane on its surface.
Saturn is 9.5 astronomical units from the Sun, approximately 886 million miles (1.4 billion kilometers).
Saturn's magnetic field is about 578 times stronger than Earth's.
The planet’s density is so low that if there were a bathtub big enough, Saturn would float on water.
Saturn’s north pole has a hexagon-shaped storm system, unlike any other weather feature in the solar system.
fake: Saturn’s rings generate enough energy to power small spacecrafts passing through them.
Titan, one of Saturn’s moons, has an active volcano that erupts ice every 20 years.
Saturn's core is made of solid gold, which gives the planet its bright yellow color.
Saturn’s hexagonal storm at the north pole is caused by electrical surges from its core.
Saturn’s rings are made of pure diamond fragments that formed in its atmosphere.
Saturn's magnetic field creates thunderstorms that produce purple lightning in the planet’s atmosphere.
Saturn's rings have slowly been shrinking, and scientists predict they will disappear within the next 1,000 years.
Saturn experiences seasons that result in its rings turning bright red during its summer months.
Saturn's largest moon, Titan, has an atmosphere similar to Earth’s and supports small, plant-like organisms.
Every 30 years, Saturn's rings shift their orbit and move closer to the planet.

true: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and is tipped over on its side with an axial tilt of 97.77 degrees.
Uranus has an equatorial diameter of 31,763 miles (51,118 kilometers), making it four times wider than Earth.
Uranus has 13 known faint rings, made mostly of dust and dark particles.
Uranus is often referred to as an 'ice giant' because it is made mostly of icy materials, including water, methane, and ammonia.
Uranus has 28 known moons, with the largest being Titania.
Uranus’ magnetic field is tipped over by nearly 60 degrees from its rotational axis, making it highly irregular.
Uranus completes one rotation in about 17 hours.
Uranus has the coldest planetary atmosphere in the solar system, with temperatures reaching -224°C (-371°F).
Winds on Uranus can reach speeds of 560 miles per hour (900 kilometers per hour).
Uranus was the first planet discovered with a telescope by astronomer William Herschel in 1781.
fake: Uranus has glowing auroras that are 100 times brighter than Earth’s northern lights.
The methane in Uranus' atmosphere makes the planet glow in the dark.
Uranus’ moons have volcanoes that eject liquid nitrogen onto the planet’s surface.
The rings of Uranus are made of finely powdered gold and copper particles.
Uranus experiences constant lightning storms that light up the entire planet’s atmosphere every few days.
The winds on Uranus are so strong that they create sonic booms that can be heard from its moons.
Uranus was once a small star that dimmed and became a planet over billions of years.
The planet has a solid iron core that generates an artificial gravitational field for its moons.
Every 50 years, Uranus’ rings double in size due to interactions with its magnetic field.
Uranus is slowly shrinking in size by 0.1% every 100 years.

true: Neptune is the eighth and farthest planet from the Sun in the solar system.
Neptune’s atmosphere consists mostly of hydrogen, helium, and methane, giving it a blue color.
Neptune is about 30 times farther from the Sun than Earth, at a distance of about 4.5 billion kilometers (2.8 billion miles).
Neptune has the strongest winds in the solar system, reaching up to 1,200 miles per hour (2,000 kilometers per hour).
Neptune has 14 known moons, with Triton being the largest.
One day on Neptune lasts about 16 hours.
Neptune’s Great Dark Spot was a storm system similar to Jupiter’s Great Red Spot but has since disappeared.
Neptune’s magnetic field is tilted 47 degrees from its rotational axis, similar to Uranus.
Neptune has five main rings, with some having bright arcs of dust and debris.
Neptune was discovered in 1846 based on mathematical predictions rather than direct observation.
fake: Neptune’s winds generate electric storms that send radio waves detectable on Earth.
The surface of Neptune is covered in vast oceans of liquid nitrogen.
Neptune’s moons glow with an intense blue light due to the planet’s magnetic field.
Neptune’s core is made of compressed methane gas, which creates artificial clouds on the planet.
Neptune's rings produce a faint musical hum that can be detected by space probes.
The planet’s magnetic field reverses direction every 20 Earth years, affecting its weather systems.
Neptune's largest moon, Triton, has active lava flows of liquid methane.
Every century, Neptune’s distance from the Sun increases by 1 million miles due to gravitational forces.
Neptune’s clouds are made of crystallized ammonia that occasionally falls as snow.
Neptune's gravity is strong enough to pull passing asteroids into its atmosphere.

true: Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006 by the International Astronomical Union.
Pluto orbits the Sun at a distance of 3.7 billion miles (5.9 billion kilometers).
Pluto has five known moons, with Charon being the largest.
A day on Pluto lasts about 153 Earth hours, equivalent to about 6.4 Earth days.
Pluto’s orbit is highly elliptical, sometimes bringing it closer to the Sun than Neptune.
Pluto's surface is made of frozen nitrogen, methane, and carbon monoxide.
Pluto's largest moon, Charon, is about half the size of Pluto.
Pluto’s atmosphere expands when it is closer to the Sun and collapses when it moves farther away.
Pluto has mountains made of water ice that reach up to 3 kilometers (9,800 feet) high.
Pluto was discovered in 1930 by Clyde Tombaugh.
fake: Pluto’s core is made of liquid helium, which causes its atmosphere to glow at night.
Pluto’s surface temperature reaches a warm 50°F during the summer months.
Pluto’s moon Charon has active volcanoes that emit glowing lava.
Pluto is the only dwarf planet with a ring system made of frozen methane crystals.
Pluto’s atmosphere is thick enough to support small clouds made of water vapor.
Pluto experiences constant meteor showers that form temporary lakes on its surface.
Pluto has a second, hidden moon that orbits inside its atmosphere and remains undetectable by Earth telescopes.
Every 10,000 years, Pluto passes through a region of space where its orbit is altered by a mysterious force.
Pluto has giant ice forests made of frozen nitrogen that grow and shrink with the seasons.
The dwarf planet has a liquid ocean beneath its surface, supporting microbial life.
